channel.title: Whats going on?
channel.description:
There has not been a newbie asking for actual programming help on something (e.g Development) for so long..
Is nobody doing anything anymore? too lazy to try and go further than using a source and changing things anyone can do with a brain? i haven't seen a valid post for the RSC Server Development section for so long. a million threads about how do i get my server online?? is nothing to do with development and there's a hundred of the threads giving help for that.
So my question is, when are some of you servers going to get going to actually try to modify the code, and not some variable/xml edits. I'm fine with supplying valid help and i'm sure many other people are as well if its a valid RSC Server Development question.
Just because RSCD is out does not mean you can sit on your asses and do nothing, there's many things you could do and have everything you've always wanted if you at least try.
P.S: this does not mean "I'm having trouble adding godspells in, i edited batch file and wrote (give god spells) but it didn't work, can you give me god spells?" Or similar.

item.title: Whats going on?
item.dc:creator: @system system
item.description:
@system wrote:

Hehe, Visual Studio does indeed have bugs aswell… I stumbled across one when at my previous work. I had made the application pretty well, and of course used the GUI-editor (nothing I prefer to do, but as the employer requires that I work fast, I almost have to use it). Then the reference within the application on a few of the buttons I had put there, somehow switched (the original buttons had been replaced with a reference to another button than they should, and thus locking it all (if I removed this reference, the buttons were removed, and if I changed the name on the other references, this couldn’t be made as there were one reference already, or something like that)). Anyhow, I had to delete all the buttons and remake it from scratch again… It worked out at last, but it made everything to take longer time.

Read full topic

item.title: Whats going on?
item.dc:creator: @Vrunk Vrunk
item.description:
@Vrunk wrote:

[quote=“xEnt, post:18, topic:213619”]Ok… but Eclipse vs Netbeans is definitely not an argument. Netbeans is crap and only keeps up with Eclipse because of its GUI editor.

Not sure if its just me, but Netbeans is a huge memory hog as well.[/quote]

I’d have to agree with you on both of those points, but the fact of the matter is that it is impossible to definitively identify something that is “the best” for all people, all development teams, at all times. It simply won’t happen.

Thus, all of these options still fall under the “my opinion, my taste, what will work best for my needs?” category (as it should)!

[hr]

Edit:
Glad everyone here likes Eclipse :rolleyes:

Read full topic

item.title: Whats going on?
item.dc:creator: @Vrunk Vrunk
item.description:
@Vrunk wrote:

[quote=“xEnt, post:16, topic:213619”]DirectX > OpenGL

Not all products Microsoft make are shit. Just most.[/quote]

#DirectX Games > #OpenGL Games

I think that’s what you meant to say. Both have their own quirks. I chose OpenGL because it is not exclusively used on Microsoft products, but still it’s like arguing…

Eclipse vs Netbeans
C++ vs Java
MacOSX vs Windows
Emacs vs VIM
Pepsi vs Coke

It’s a matter of taste/opinion, along with what you want the system to do for you. Pick something that suits your needs, and stick to it.

Read full topic

item.title: Whats going on?
item.dc:creator: @Vrunk Vrunk
item.description:
@Vrunk wrote:

xEnt:

Don’t use java to make a game imo. the only reason Runescape got lucky is because of the gameplay and compatibility also cause it was web based.

If I’m going to write a game, it’s going to be in a language that I understand and enjoy. There is plenty of open source middle-ware to use that will speed development along. My server will most definitely be written in Java, but my Client is still up in the air (although currently being written in Java).

It’s going to be a LOT of work, regardless of what language I choose to write the Client in. The main reason I chose Java is for the very fact that I can make it run in an Applet. I’m going to be using OpenGL for rendering. Fuck DirectX and Microsoft, I’m a fan of Sun.

That being said, I’m going to make it as a hobby. If it turns into something big, that’s great. If not, that’s fine too, because I will have learned so much as I go along, and enjoyed the time I had to write it.

Read full topic
